metadata.title: Feldenkrais Method (FM)
description: Considered a form of complementary and alternative medicine, the FM is a movement-education  technique designed to promote physical function and well-being. Developed by Moshe Feldenkrais, a physicist, engineer, and judo practitioner, in response to a knee injury for which surgery was suggested, the core principle is to first improve one’s kinesthetic and proprioceptive self-awareness via guided practice and ultimately to transform unhealthy habits, movements, and postures into movements that are comfortable and easy(1)
The underlying theory is that poor habitual movement patterns result in injury and pain and that multiple repetitions that concern the entire body lay down new neuromuscular patterns(2)

FM is an experiential process or set of processes in which the client or group(3) –is guided through a series of movement and sensation-based explorations –practices sensing the differences between two or more options to achieve a task –discerns and judges which option is more positive (easier, pleasurable, less effort) –is encouraged to find further distinctions and improvements to apply in the learning framework

It is a process in which the client(4) –creates an environment that is comfortable, safe, and conducive to creating the movement –greatly reduces the amount of effort required for that movement by making fine discriminations about the effects of force acting on the system from inside and/or outside –has as a goal to develop a rich understanding of changes throughout the system produced by small perturbations(4)

Two delivery methods are offered to the public – Awareness Through Movement (ATM) and Functional Integration (FI). They differ in practice but are similar in principle and process –ATM -Group, verbally directed classes(3) -Participants are encouraged to move at their own pace and to experiment(1,5) -Client introduces the experimental forces into his or her own system with the intention of understanding how the body as a whole responds(4) -At no time are the students told how to do a movement; instead, they are allowed to discover how to embody the movement(6)  -Nearly all lessons (around 100 total) involve attention, perception, imagination, and cognition(6) –FI -A hands-on  approach to facilitate movement and awareness(5) -Instructor provides more active assistance with the discovery process by gently and precisely moving the student(1) -The instructor provides the force inputs and the client attends to the changes caused by the perturbations(4) -Much of the learning takes place at the neurological level as the nervous system receives sensory information(6) -There is no strict expectation by the practitioner about what specific movement might emerge(4) -Sessions often take place on firm Feldenkrais table or on floor(6) -This method may include some soft-tissues  work to relieve excessive muscle tension, spasm, or muscle tightness(7) –In practice and if possible, it is common to move back and forth between ATM and FI(4)

The FM places emphasis on relaxation of muscles on stretch and distracting and compressing joints for sensory awareness, which reflect combined proprioceptive techniques to enhance body schema awareness(8) –Taking muscles off stretch slows afferent firing, which decreases overload of the CNS –Compression and distraction of joints enhances specific input from a body part and combines it with facilitating input of lesser intensity from other body segments

ATM can be considered a form of relaxation training as it combines sensory awareness, movements of the limbs and trunk, deep breathing, conscious relaxation procedures, and self-massage  to alter muscle imbalances and abnormal posture in the interest of remediating muscle tension and pain(9)
reimbursement: Most insurance plans do not cover the FM. Exceptions can be workers’ compensation, automobile insurance cases, or cases in which the practitioner teaching the technique is also a physical therapist (PT)(5) Indications for Feldenkrais Method
contraindications precautions to test: For detailed information on the examination of specific conditions for which FM is being recommended, see the Clinical Review  associated with each condition

contraindications precautions to examina: For detailed information on the examination of specific conditions for which FM is being recommended, see the Clinical Review  associated with each condition

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Document the history of the condition that has led to the discussion of FM as a form of treatment

course of treatment.medical management: Document the medical management of the condition. Document if the FM is being suggested as an adjunct to the medical management of the condition
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications clinician has prescribed for the condition; are they being taken? Are they effectively controlling symptoms? Depending on the condition, patients may be on a variety of medications
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Tests required will depend on the condition for which the FM method is being considered
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help. Document whether the patient has tried the FM in the past or similar movement education techniques (e.g., Alexander technique) and, if the patient has, document the reason the technique was chosen and the response to it
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Document factors and length of time each item is performed before the symptoms of the condition come on or are eased
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms, as indicated
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms associated with condition for which the FM is being considered (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling)
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 010  scale to assess symptoms at their best, worst, and at the moment (specifically, address if pain is present now and how much)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (AM, mid-day, PM, night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night that are associated with condition
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician
history of present illness.respiratory status: If condition has effect on breathing, be sure to record baseline measurements and any use of supplemental oxygen; obtain any pulmonary function test results -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe_________________________

past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems including diabetes, cancer, cardiovascular disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Document if the current condition is limiting the patient’s ability to participate at work, school, or in hobbies
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Document if the patient is currently experiencing functional limitations associated with the condition and/or requiring the use of assistive or adaptive equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Document number of stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc., if applicable; identify if there are barriers to independence in the home and if any modifications are necessary

relevant tests and measures.general: ›Relevant tests and measures  (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Document patient’s height, weight, and BMI; measure for leg-length  discrepancy as indicated
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Document what assistive and adaptive devices are being used, if applicable
relevant tests and measures.balance: Evaluate both dynamic and static balance with Romberg test or single limb stance (eyes open and eyes closed) and with Functional Reach Test (FRT), Berg Balance Scale, or other appropriate measures for the condition
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Check peripheral pulses as indicatedAssess if indicated by conditionAssess transfers on and off Feldenkrais table if applicable and getting up from floor if patient is considering ATM. Timed Up and Go (TUG) test or FIM may be used if appropriate to condition
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Assess for any deviations due to condition. Document gait speed and other gait parameters if indicated. Utilize Dynamic Gait Index (DGI) to assess gait safety if indicatedAssess joint mobility throughout extremities and spine and note any areas of hypo-  or hypermobilityCareful examination of abnormal movements and postures as well as assessment of tone
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) can be used to assess upper and lower extremity (LE) strength as indicated
relevant tests and measures.posture: Thoroughly assess patient’s posture and note any abnormalities or deviations
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Assess ROMof all joints and flexibility of applicable muscles, noting any limitations that may interfere with a person’s ability to participate in FM or that require attention or could benefit from specific FM exercises
relevant tests and measures.special tests specific to diagnosis: Utilize appropriate special test for the condition –Due to the broad range of applications of the FM, researchers in Australia used a pre/post-test  design to establish that the Patient-specific  Functional Scale(PSFS), Pain Outcome Profile (POP), and Short Form 12v2 Health Questionnaire were suitable for detecting changes in client function before and after a series of Feldenkrais sessions(12) -Eleven Feldenkrais practitioners submitted data on 48 clients. Each practitioner administered the three questionnaires before starting a Feldenkrais session and then repeated the questionnaires after the session -Practitioners and clients found the tools quick and easy to use and practitioners reported that the PSFS was the most useful questionnaire in practice -On the PSFS, which measures ability to perform everyday tasks, clients improved, on average, 3.8 points -On the POP, which measures decreases in pain, clients had significant improvement in current pain, physical index, and affective index; and on the Short Form 12v2, which measures quality of life, clients showed significant improvement in six of the eight domains
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Assess orientation to name, place, time, and situation; attention, short-  and long-term  memory; and problem solving, as indicated. Take into consideration the importance of attention to movement during the FM exercise before suggesting

other: Patients with a diagnosis for which this procedure is used may be at risk for falls. Ensure that patient and family/ caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention  strategies

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The FM method has been applied in varied domains across countries, from general education of children with learning issues to enhancing performance in sports and theater. It is of interest clinically due to the appeal of basing a health recovery process on a learning paradigm and the empowerment that follows(3) Pain, poor posture, fall proneness, movement disorders, stiffness, poor self-efficacy  in dealing with chronic pain, poor body awareness, quality of life with chronic disease, poor lung function
other considerations: Researchers in France using functional MRI during an FM intervention on the foot in 21 adults came to the following conclusions:(13) –Short, non-intrusive  sensorimotor intervention performed during an FM session can have short-term  effects on spontaneous cortical activity in functionally related brain regions –A global intervention (practitioner focused on connection between foot and body) demonstrated increased resting state activity in higher-order  motor areas of the participant when compared to local intervention (practitioner focused on foot and ankle), supporting the hypothesis of engagement of action-related  neural processes during global interventions

Authors of a survey of 392 United States Guild Certified Feldenkrais Teachers found the following characteristics (response rate was 30.5% or 392/1,287)(11) –Ninety percent had college degrees –36.2% or 142 held conventional healthcare licenses, of whom 93 were PTs, 15 were occupational therapists, and 5 were nurses –Mean age was 55.7 years –Eighty-three  percent were women and most practiced in California (n = 100) and New York (n = 34) –Most were in part-time  practice and saw < 10 students per week individually and < 10 students per week for group lessons –Their students tended to be women, 45–64  years old, who sought lessons due to pain. A quarter of students self-referred,  a fifth were referred by conventional healthcare providers, and two-thirds  paid for services directly

Teachers, Assistant Trainers, Trainers –Training programs for FM teachers are held throughout the world (30 countries) and follow international accreditation standards(6) -The Feldenkrais Guild of North America governs the FM in the United States(5) -Training programs for teachers are accredited and require about 1,200 hours of training that occurs over 3 to 4 years -FM, anatomy, biomechanics, and communication techniques are covered, with a significant portion of the program being hands-on  and with the practitioner-in-training  being the student –According to the FM website in Australia, there are 4 certified trainers and 16 assistant trainers in Australia and 4 assistant trainers in Japan ( https://www.feldenkrais.org.au/ )
treatment summary: There is not much evidence-based  literature evaluating the efficacy of the FM(1,2,3,4)

Researchers who conducted a qualitative content analysis study of the 16 lessons of the “Getting Grounded Gracefully” series (an ATM-based program designed to improve balance and mobility in older adults) concluded that the FM contained many elements consistent with current theories of motor skill acquisition and postural control(10) –Lessons were transcribed and analyzed for movement tasks that were then coded by two coders according to the motor learning principles and/or postural control tasks present. Inter-coder  reliability was reported as good –Content analysis revealed the following motor skill acquisition elements and postural control skills: -Motor skill acquisition elements – internal feedback, repetition, variability of practice using exploratory learning approach -Postural control skills – intersegmental coordination of ankle/hip/trunk synergies, control of center of mass over base of support –Key findings: -Extensive involvement of trunk flexibility and control in balance activities -Intensive attention to internal feedback which was linked to body awareness training

Applications for older adults –Feldenkrais exercises result in positive changes in balance, mobility, fear of falls, and balance confidence(14) -Based on a stratified RCT conducted in the United States with 47 older adults (mean age 75.6) assigned to either intervention or control group -Intervention was 3 one-hour  Feldenkrais sessions a week for 5 weeks using the ATM technique that were taught by a certified Feldenkrais teacher. The focus of the exercises was improving balance and mobility. The control group was a wait-list  control -Outcome measures were tandem stance for balance, TUG and TUGc (TUG with added cognitive task) for mobility, GAITRite Walkway system for gait parameters, ABC for balance confidence, and Falls Efficacy Scale for fear of falling -Balance and mobility significantly increased while fear of falling decreased in intervention group. Balance confidence and mobility showed significant improvements while performing a cognitive task -Authors suggested further studies with more total treatments to evaluate effectiveness of Feldenkrais exercises long-term.  Studies comparing FM to other interventions that improve balance and prevent falls would be valuable –Both Pilates and the FM are effective in improving balance and decreasing propensity to fall in ambulatory older adults although Pilates was found to be superior in improving quality of life (QoL)(15) -Based on an RCT conducted in India with 60 ambulatory older adults living in nursing homes who were assigned to either Pilates intervention (PI), FM intervention, or control group -Intervention was thrice weekly for 6 weeks: PI was 45–60  minutes of exercises, FM was ATM method with 5 lessons (10 repetitions with 2-minute  rest between exercises), and control group walked for a total of 22 minutes -Outcome measures were Functional Reach Test (FRT), TUG, DGI, and RAND-36  Measure of Health-Related Quality of Life, measured at baseline and after 6 weeks of training -PI and FM groups were significantly better than controls in all outcome measures; however, PI was found to be more clinically effective when compared to FM in all outcome scores –In a similar non-randomized  study from Australia, researchers suggested that a FM balance class may improve mobility and balance in older adults(16) -Twenty-six  community-dwelling  older adults who had signed up for FM balance classes (again using the program “Getting Grounded Gracefully” for a total of 20 treatments) as part of a falls-prevention  program were compared to 37 controls who volunteered in response to an advertisement for participants in a balance study  -Baseline measures were similar except that control group had significantly more confidence in their balance as measured by ABC questionnaire -Main outcome measures were ABC questionnaire, Four Square Step Test, and self-selected  gait speed (using GAITRite instrumented gait mat). Compared to control group, FM group made significant improvement in all outcome measures –A series of FM classes, twice a week for 30 weeks, taken by 15 patients with osteoarthritis (average age 67) improved performance on the Four Square Step Test and on some gait parameters (anterior pelvic tilt reduction, increased knee extension at heel contact, and knee flexion at swing). Participants also reported greater ease of movement in this Australian study(17)

Applications for pain disorders –The FM was an effective intervention for 61 patients with chronic neck/scapular pain and visual impairment according to an RCT conducted in Sweden(18) -Patients with visual impairment were chosen because of the hands-on  communication inthe FM which could benefit this population -Intervention was one 2-hour  session a week for 12 weeks held by an experienced licensed FM PT. FM was applied in both forms (ATM and FI) with the aim of increasing awareness of sensory afferents, exploring habitual but unconscious muscular patterns, breaking stereotyped movement patterns, and enabling self-care  for pain -Outcome measures were the V AS (during standardized palpation of the left and right occipital, upper trapezius, and levator scapulae muscles), the self-assessed  degree of pain on the Visual, Musculoskeletal, and Balance Complaints questionnaire, and the Medical Outcomes Study 36-item  Short-Form  Health Survey (SF-36)  bodily pain scale -Patients undergoing FM reported significantly less pain than the controls according to the V AS and Visual, Musculoskeletal, and Balance Complaints questionnaire ratings at post-treatment  follow-up and 1-year  follow-up –Authors of a 2011 systematic review examining the effectiveness of the FM in preventive and symptomatic treatment of LBP in adults concluded that available studies do not prove the effectiveness of the FM(19) -The authors could find only 2 articles that met inclusion criteria –Researchers who conducted a 2017 RCT comparing FT and back school found no difference in outcomes for patients with nonspecific chronic LBP(24) -Based on a study of 53 patients in Italy with chronic LBP -Patients were randomly assigned to either a 3-month back school or a 3-month  FM program -Outcome measures were V AS, McGill Pain Questionnaire (MPQ), Waddell Disability Index, Short Form-36 Health Survey (SF-36),  and Multidimensional Assessment of Interoceptive Awareness Questionnaire (MAIA) -The researchers found no differences in outcomes at end of program or at 3-month  follow-up  and suggested that FM could be used as an alternative to back school –Authors of two qualitative studies evaluated the FM in adults with chronic pain and found benefits other than pain relief -Improvements in movement ability and body awareness were themes described in the diaries and interviews conducted with 14 women with non-specific  neck and shoulder pain who attended 10 group sessions over 6–7 weeks in a study in Sweden(20) -The authors did note that participants found the exercises difficult to perform utilizing self-training  on a daily basis -Improved self-efficacy  through somatic education and awareness was the theme identified through semi-structured interviews with 11 adults with chronic-episodic  back pain who had been attending ATM lessons in the FM method in Australia(21) -The authors credited individuals’ perception of having control of their back pain by awareness through movement as empowering

Neurological disorders –Findings from an RCT conducted in Brazil on the effects of FM-based  exercise on QoL and depression in older adults with Parkinson’s disease (PD) indicated that a program based on the FM can contribute to the QoL of patients with PD and decrease the rate of depression(22) -Thirty patients randomly assigned to intervention and control. Intervention group underwent 50 sessions (twice a week for 25 weeks) of a PT program based on FM with emphasis on chosen ways to breathe, roll, sit, stand, squat, and walk easily and efficiently -The control group received 1 week of educational lectures(fall prevention, medication use, managing ADLs) immediately after baseline assessment  -Both groups assessed at baseline and at conclusion of intervention. Outcome measures were the Parkinson’s Disease Quality of Life (PDQL) questionnaire and the Beck Depression Inventory -Authors suggest that the success of the FM indicates the importance of interventions that work with awareness of movement for the promotion of wellness for patients with PD

COPD –The FM significantly improved functional capacity and lung function among patients with COPD in an 8-week  study conducted in Malaysia(23) -Based on an observational pilot study with 11 patients with COPD attending ATM classes. Activities included relaxation exercises, breathing exercises, floor exercises for trunk and pelvic movements, and upper limb movements -It was not clear from study how many treatments per week but descriptions of the lessons would imply one session per week of about one-hour duration -Outcome measures were 6MWT for functional capacity, forced expiratory volume in 1-s, predicted percent (FEV1 pred %) for lung function, and Health-Related Quality of Life questionnaire

See Description and Indications for Feldenkrais method and Guidelines for use of Feldenkrais method above . Problem Goal Intervention Expected Progression Home Program Poor posture, mobility, with fear of falling and decreased balance confidence in older adults _ _ Chronic pain _ _ Decreased self-efficacy _ _ Decreased movement and body awareness _ _ Lack of motor control _ Depression, decreased quality of life due to chronic illness (PD, MS, etc.) _ COPDImprovements in posture, mobility with less fear of falling and increased balance confidence _ Decreased pain _ Improved self-efficacy and empowerment _ Increase in body movement and awareness _ Increase in motor control _ Less depression and improved quality of life _ _ Improved lung functionTherapeutic Strategies:  FM lessons with focus to first improve one’s kinesthetic and proprioceptive self- awareness via guided practice, and ultimately to transform unhealthy habits, movements, and postures into movements that are comfortable and easy(1) _ “Getting Grounded Gracefully” for older adultsProgression is decided by teacher and patient as goals are metGenerally, not done as treatment dependent on certified teacher. One study did report that participants found the exercises difficult to perform as self-training on a daily basis(20) .

improvements in posture; mobility with l: Falls Efficacy Scale for fear of falling
Timed Sit to Stand (3 times) or Five times sit to stand(FTSTST)
increased movement and body awareness, m: Movement assessment, ROM, patient report, FIM
less depression and improved quality of: RAND-36  Measure of Health-Related  Quality of LifeBeck Depression Inventory

maintenance or prevention: The following groups of people tend to benefit from the FM:(5) High-performing  individuals – athletes, artists, actors, musicians, dancers, martial arts participants, singers, computer operators, equestrian riders Individuals interested in improving their particular physical state or seeking personal enlightenment
patient education: Various Feldenkrais organizations across the world have FM information North America – Feldenkrais Guild of North America – https://www.feldenkrais.com/ Australia, Japan – Australian Feldenkrais Guild –https://www.feldenkrais.org.au/ Israel and Europe –European  and Israeli Feldenkrais Training and Accreditation Board, known as EuroTAB –http:// www.eurotab.org/ Coding Matrix References are rated using the following codes, listed in order of strength: MPublished meta-analysis SRPublished systematic or integrative literature review RCTPublished research (randomized controlled trial) RPublished research (not randomized controlled trial) CCase histories, case studies GPublished guidelinesRVPublished review of the literature RUPublished research utilization report QIPublished quality improvement report LLegislation PGRPublished government report PFRPublished funded reportPPPolicies, procedures, protocols XPractice exemplars, stories, opinions GIGeneral or background information/texts/reports UUnpublished research, reviews, poster presentations or other such materials CPConference proceedings, abstracts, presentation
